Award.AwardTitle: Efficient, Robust and Soluble Electron Transport Polymers
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Robust, reliable and flexible devices/circuits could be transformational for industries ranging from healthcare and environmental quality to energy and security. To attain this vision, new materials that can effectively transport charges are needed. In this regard, polymers that transport electrons are especially challenging. This proposal aims to design and synthesize new molecular structures that will not only readily transport electrons, but also be compatible with low-cost fabrication techniques. The research will impact a range of electronics technologies that are the mainstay of our society. Also, students will realize benefits from the multidisciplinary nature of the program. All students participating in this program will be cross-trained and, where necessary, will further expand their knowledge and experience through additional collaborations. They will develop leadership skills and have access to professional development workshops through participation in the Georgia Tech Polymer Network-Student Association. The PI is committed to diversity in her recruiting, education and training activities.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Polymeric semiconductors have a number of advantages that derive from their inherent flexibility, solubility, and low temperature processability. Such competitive characteristics allow for the implementation of pi-conjugated polymers in low-cost, light-weight and large-area flexible optoelectronics. The application space ranges from simple transistor devices to photovoltaics for energy conversion, to light emitting diodes, to thermo-electrics and sensors. Ubiquitous availability of such devices will contribute the nation's needs in healthcare, environmental quality, energy and security. To enable the range of envisioned devices, both hole and electron transporting materials are required. Among these, polymers that exhibit electron transport characteristics are much more limited in their availability due to poor oxidative stability and high sensitivity to moisture. This study will identify polymer architectures having extended pi-conjugation to maintain a low bandgap, a low HOMO level for enhanced stability, and effective pi-pi intermolecular interactions to improved charge transport performance. The investigation will explore alternative alkyl side chains for their ability to solubilize targeted polymers in common organic solvents, synthesize both homopolymers and donor-acceptor architectures to tune HOMO/LUMO energy levels, characterize targeted materials via spectroscopic, microscopic and electrical methods to identify significant materials structure-processing-property parameters, and fabricate field effect transistor, photovoltaic and thermo-electric devices to evaluate the impact of the proposed approach. Key, synthetically accessible molecular components will be identified that will provide for an extension of semiconducting polymer pi-conjugation length allowing for the orientation and alignment that are an imperative for charge transport. The studies will identify efficient, robust, soluble electron transport polymer materials for flexible electronics applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Solution-processed conjugated polymers offer a route to the low cost, mass production of printable, flexible electronic devices such as flexible/stretchable displays, sensor arrays, biomedical devices, solar cells and thermoelectrics. To realize this range of applications, high performance, solution processable, hole and electron transport materials are required.

To date, a number of organic p-channel (hole transporting) and ambipolar semiconductors with relatively high hole mobilities (µ > 1 cm2V-1s-1) have been commercialized, though the range of n-channel (electron transporting) conjugated polymers is significantly more limited. Thus, attention is shifting to the design and development of the n-channel counterparts. Potentially useful building blocks can be found among the various electron deficient organic structures, such as diketopyrrolopyrrole (DPP) and naphthalene diimide (NDI). NDI in particular has been extensively studied for its planarity and high ionization potential (i.e., low lying HOMO energy level) that can significantly contribute to the n-channel characteristics of resulting polymers.

Here, another electron deficient building block was identified, namely, 2,2’-bithiazole (BTz). When compared to electron-rich bithiophene (BT), bithiazole was found to significantly increase the ionization potential and electron affinity (lower the HOMO and LUMO energy levels) of copolymers comprised of the bithiazole and diketopyrrolopyrrole. A series of diketopyrrolopyrrole-thiazole (DPP-Tz) copolymers differing in the number of thiazoles in each repeating unit were synthesized via Stille condensation. The resultant materials, poly(diketopyrrolopyrrole-bithiazole), PDPP-2Tz, and poly(terthiazole-diketopyrrolopyrrole), PDPP-4Tz were characterized by NMR, UV-vis, gel permeation chromatography, differential scanning calorimetry and thermogravimetric analysis.  The polymers were also prepared in thin-film form via solution processing and their morphologies were examined using atomic force microscopy and x-ray diffraction techniques.  Additionally, the semiconductors were incorporated into thin-film transistor devices to examine their electrical properties/charge transport characteristics. Unlike traditional D (donor)-A copolymers, PDPP4Tz is an all acceptor copolymer that is a unipolar n-channel polymeric semiconductor comprised of exclusively electron withdrawing moieties. Preliminary characterization points to PDPP4Tz possessing electron mobility reaching 0.07 cm2V-1s-1 when incorporated into an organic field-effect transistor. Notably, DFT calculations show that the natural transition orbital is delocalized along the polymer backbone for both the hole and electron. This feature underscores the difference between PDPP4Tz with regard to typical D-A copolymers that generally display a localized electron NTO.

Building on these results, an alternative acceptor-acceptor polymer based on a copolymer of naphthalene diimide (NDI), with bithiazole was designed and synthesized.  PNDI2Tz exhibited a field effect electron mobility in the range of up to 0.08 cm2/Vs and GIWAXS characterization suggested that when deposited onto silicon substrates, the polymer adopts an intrinsically face-on orientation. The impact of deposition conditions, such as shear coating speed and dielectric surface effects on polymer charge transport characteristics was interrogated. Solution processing, coating conditions, and dielectric surface effects were seen to significantly impact thin-film surface morphology, interfacial morphology, thin-film crystallinity and charge transport pathways. In addition, n-channel conjugated polymers are extremely sensitive to charge traps such as hydroxyl groups on clean silicon dioxide as gate dielectric. To cap those hydroxyl groups, three common surface modifiers, octadecyltrichlorosilane, hexamethyldisilazane, and phenyltrichlorosilane were evaluated. Blade coating conditions were optimized (speed, angle, temperature, etc) which facilitated the investigation of surface effects on transport properties. The electron transport polymers identified in this program have characteristics that are of significant interest for applications in energy conversion devices such as solar cells and thermoelectrics.

The program supported one full-time graduate student, who actively engaged in mentoring several undergraduates. The results have led to one peer reviewed publication, with several additional publications currently in prepraration. The graduate student presented the research results in several venues, including national and international conferences; the undergraduate students participated in poster sessions at Georgia Tech and at national conferences.


Last Modified: 07/05/2018
Modified by: Elsa Reichmanis
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Solution-processed conjugated polymers offer a route to the low cost, mass production of printable, flexible electronic devices such as flexible/stretchable displays, sensor arrays, biomedical devices, solar cells and thermoelectrics. To realize this range of applications, high performance, solution processable, hole and electron transport materials are required. NDI in particular has been extensively studied for its planarity and high ionization potential (i.e., low lying HOMO energy level) that can significantly contribute to the n-channel characteristics of resulting polymers. Here, another electron deficient building block was identified, namely, 2,2?-bithiazole (BTz). The results have led to one peer reviewed publication, with several additional publications currently in prepraration. The graduate student presented the research results in several venues, including national and international conferences; the undergraduate students participated in poster sessions at Georgia Tech and at national conferences.
